docs.lead_paragraph: Parents often fail to perceive when their child is overweight. In a recent study, parents were asked to describe their child's weight in words. They were then presented with a series of sketches, below, and asked to choose the drawing that most closely resembled their child. Graph tracks whether the child was: not overweight Overweight At risk for overweight And compared those answers to according to whether the parents said the children were: Overweight About right A little overweight A little underweight underweight Of the children who were actually overweight or at risk to be overweight, only 36 percent of parents described them that way. But 70 percent of those parents selected one of the heavier images when choosing a sketch. Graph tracks whether the child was: not overweight Overweight At risk for overweight Graph also compared how parents (looked at images below and) said their child was... Average Lighter Combined in chart Heavier Diagram/Chart shows sketches of children (boys and girls) ages 2-5, 6-9, and 10-13 who would be considered lighter, average, and heavier body types. Note: The body mass index (BMI) was used to determine if each child was overweight. A percentile of 95 or higher was considered overweight (85-94 considered at risk for overweight). (Sources by Dr. Helen J. Binns, Northwestern University; Pediatrics)
